title: Messaging tools: send_message, check_messages
Phase 1: Core MCP server
description:
Implement the foundational biff commands as an MCP server.

Commands: /mesg, /who, /plan, /finger, /biff on|off
Local relay for same-machine communication.
Single-user value from /plan and session awareness.
.biff file configuration (relay URL, whitelisted IDs).

Exit criteria: an engineer can install biff, set their plan, see active sessions, and send a message to a teammate on the same machine.

title: /plan auto-expands beads IDs to include issue title
description: When a user passes a beads ID to /plan (e.g. /plan biff-x73), detect the ID pattern and auto-expand it to include the issue title: 'biff-x73: MCP server scaffold with HTTP/stdio transport'. Requires the plan tool to shell out to bd show or read .beads/issues.jsonl to resolve the title. Falls back gracefully to the raw string if the ID doesn't match a known issue.

title: Spike: MCP notification rendering and subprocess handoff
description:
Validate two critical feasibility questions before committing to the full Phase 1 implementation.

**Question 1: MCP notifications for receiving messages**
Can an MCP server push a notification to Claude Code that renders visibly in the terminal? Test:
- Create a minimal MCP server that fires a notification after a delay
- Verify it appears in the Claude Code session without a tool call
- Assess rendering quality (plain text? formatted? inline with conversation?)

**Question 2: Subprocess handoff for /talk**
Can an MCP server spawn an interactive subprocess that takes over terminal I/O, then return control to Claude Code cleanly? Test:
- MCP tool call spawns a simple interactive process (e.g., a chat loop)
- User types directly to the subprocess (no LLM intermediation)
- Process exits, Claude Code resumes normally
- Assess the UX transition (seamless or jarring?)

**Exit criteria:**
- Clear yes/no on both questions with evidence
- If notifications work: document the API and rendering constraints
- If subprocess handoff works: document the mechanism and UX quality
- If either fails: document alternatives and revised approach for /mesg and /talk

**Timeframe:** 1-2 days
notes:
Spike results (2026-02-13):

Q1 (MCP notifications render?): NO - notifications/message silently dropped by Claude Code (issue #3174, closed not planned).
Q2 (Subprocess handoff?): NO - stdio transport reserves stdout for JSON-RPC, no PTY allocation.

ALTERNATIVE DISCOVERED: HTTP transport + tools/list_changed
- FastMCP HTTP transport works (Streamable HTTP + SSE)
- Dynamic tool descriptions update via remove_tool/re-register
- notifications/tools/list_changed automatically sent on SSE channel
- Server-side validated via curl (all 5 checks pass)
- Same pattern used by Slack MCP server in production
- Claude Code end-to-end test pending (needs new session)

RECOMMENDATION: Proceed with HTTP transport architecture for Phase 1.
Architecture documented in docs/prd/biff-phase1-communication.md and docs/sparc/phase1-implementation.md
close_reason: Server-side validation complete. All 5 checks pass. HTTP transport + tools/list_changed is viable. Architecture recommendation: proceed with HTTP transport. Claude Code e2e test deferred to new session.

title: Phase 3: Real-time conversation, pairing, and security
description:
Add synchronous communication and the session-sharing feature.

Commands: /talk, /pair
/talk: real-time bidirectional text conversation between two terminals.
/pair: invite a teammate to send input to your Claude Code session with explicit consent model.
End-to-end encryption for all message types.
Security audit of the permission model.

Exit criteria: two engineers can hold a real-time conversation and pair on a Claude session with proper consent and encryption.

title: .biff config file parser
Message watcher + dynamic tool descriptions
close_reason: PR #13 merged. Dynamic check_messages descriptions implemented with refresh on every tool call.

title: Multi-process transport tests: two biff serve subprocesses over stdio
description: Spawn two real biff serve processes (--user kai, --user eric, same --data-dir) connected over stdio. Exercise MCP wire protocol through actual pipes, not FastMCPTransport. Catches serialization bugs, process lifecycle issues, stdio framing. Use subprocess + MCP client library to connect. Generates transcripts like E2E tests but with real transport.
close_reason: Subprocess tests shipped in PR #9: 15 tests over StdioTransport, cross-process state verified

title: Integration tests + quality gates
Phase 4: Hosted relay service (biff teams)
description:
Launch the managed biff teams offering on top of the Supabase relay (Phase 2).

Since the relay IS a Supabase project, the "hosted" story is largely solved by Phase 2. Phase 4 adds the operational and commercial layer:

- Default hosted Supabase project managed by biff (the free/public relay)
- Team isolation via Supabase RLS policies and per-team channels
- Audit logs via Postgres queries on the messages table
- Admin controls: team membership, permissions, onboarding/offboarding
- End-to-end encryption (client-side, keys managed outside Supabase)
- Compliance exports (message history, audit trails)
- Billing integration if needed (usage-based on message volume)
- 99.9% uptime — inherited from Supabase Pro plan

Self-hosted teams skip this entirely — they manage their own Supabase project.

Exit criteria: a team can sign up for biff teams, get a managed relay with admin controls, audit logging, and encryption.

title: Spike: validate tools/list_changed in Claude Code
notes: Server-side validation complete (5/5 checks pass). Remaining: Claude Code e2e test — does Claude Code act on notifications/tools/list_changed and show updated tool descriptions? Requires session restart with biff-spike registered in .mcp.json.
close_reason: E2E validated: Claude Code acts on tools/list_changed. Dynamic tool descriptions update in real-time. Full chain confirmed: simulate_message → remove/re-register tool → list_changed notification on SSE → Claude Code refreshes → updated description visible to Claude.

title: Storage layer: inbox.py and sessions.py
close_reason: MessageStore + SessionStore with 35 tests. JSONL/JSON backed, atomic writes, malformed data recovery.

title: Phase 2: Network relay and team commands
description:
Enable cross-machine messaging and team-level commands via a hosted relay.

See prfaq.tex for authoritative product vision, phasing, and scope.

## Architecture

punt-labs runs the default hosted relay. Teams connect by having a .biff file in their repo with the relay URL. No accounts to create, no third-party services to sign up for — pip install biff-mcp + clone = connected.

Teams that want data sovereignty can self-host the same relay.

## Data Source Mapping

Each command's data lives in one of two places: GitHub (persistent, repo-specific) or the relay (ephemeral/short-lived, real-time).

| Command | Durability | Source | Notes |
|---------|-----------|--------|-------|
| /plan "text" | Persistent | GitHub | Like ~/.plan was a file. Survives sessions, disconnects, everything. |
| /who | Ephemeral | Relay | Live presence. Only meaningful in real-time. |
| /finger @user | Both | GitHub + Relay | Persistent plan from GitHub, online/offline from relay. |
| /biff on/off | Ephemeral | Relay | Session-level toggle. Gone when you disconnect. |
| /mesg @user | Store-and-forward | Relay | POP model: relay holds until read, then discards. |
| /wall | Ephemeral | Relay | Miss it if you're offline. Matches UNIX. |
| /hive | Ephemeral | Relay | Temporary group, dissolves on /hive off. |
| /send @user | TBD | TBD | Design pending. |
| /cr @user | TBD | TBD | Design pending. |
| /talk @user | Ephemeral | Relay | Real-time conversation. No transcript. |
| /pair @user | Ephemeral | Relay | Live session sharing. |

## Relay Persistence Model: POP Mail

The relay follows a POP mail model — retrieve-and-delete:

- Messages are stored on the relay only until the recipient reads them
- Once read, the relay discards them. Biff is not a system of record.
- Offline users' messages queue on the relay until they next connect
- /wall is even simpler: ephemeral broadcast to connected clients, no storage at all

This is a thin persistence requirement. The relay needs a mailbox per user that drains on read, not a database.

NATS JetStream consumers with ack-and-delete implement this pattern directly.

## UNIX Lineage

The commands evoke BSD UNIX utilities but adapt where modern usage demands it:

- /wall matches UNIX exactly: ephemeral broadcast, miss it if you're offline
- /plan matches UNIX exactly: persistent file (was ~/.plan), readable via /finger
- /mesg departs from UNIX write (which failed if user offline) toward mail semantics (store-and-forward), because async messaging between distributed developers requires queuing
- /biff on/off matches UNIX biff: controls whether you receive notifications

## Implementation Backend: Candidate Assessment

Three options were evaluated for the relay. Research includes Python SDK maturity, hosting models, delivery guarantees, presence support, and self-hosting complexity.

### Option A: Supabase (Postgres + Realtime + Presence)

**Pros:**
- Integrated auth, RLS, and Postgres — one platform for storage + realtime
- Cheap at small scale ($0-25/mo for 100 users)
- Free tier covers 200 concurrent connections, 2M messages
- Broadcast latency is good (6ms median at 32k users)

**Cons:**
- No delivery guarantees. Docs: "The server does not guarantee that every message will be delivered."
- realtime-py stability issues. Archived Aug 2025. Silent data loss during reconnection.
- Presence is ephemeral — status vanishes on disconnect.
- Postgres Changes is single-threaded. No published throughput benchmarks.
- Self-hosting = 13 Docker containers.
- You'd build a message queue on Postgres anyway.

**Verdict:** Reliability gaps make it unsuitable for store-and-forward messaging.

### Option B: NATS + JetStream (Recommended)

**Pros:**
- Purpose-built for messaging. JetStream for persistence and delivery guarantees.
- KV store for presence with TTL, watch API. Maps to /who, /finger. ~50 LOC.
- JetStream consumers with ack-and-delete implement POP model directly.
- Mature Python client: nats-py v2.13.1 (Feb 2026), 145K weekly PyPI downloads, full asyncio.
- Self-hosting: single Go binary (<20MB).
- Managed hosting: Synadia Cloud (free personal, $49/mo starter).
- Handles 100K msg/s on single node — far beyond Biff's needs.
- Ephemeral-by-default messaging matches POP model.

**Cons:**
- No built-in presence. DIY with KV store + heartbeats (~50 LOC).
- No built-in auth UI. User identity separate from connection auth.
- Synadia Cloud free tier limited to 10 connections.
- Self-hosters need monitoring setup.

**Verdict:** Best fit. Messaging-first design, POP model maps directly to JetStream consumers, self-hosting is trivial.

### Option C: Matrix Protocol (Eliminated)

Over-engineered for this use case. Presence is resource-heavy, Python SDK immature, self-hosting requires a homeserver, federation adds unwanted complexity. See previous analysis.

## Open Design Questions

1. **Auth flow** — How do MCP servers authenticate to the relay? Per-user or per-team?
2. **Reconnection strategy** — Replay missed messages from JetStream on reconnect?
3. **Dual-mode conflict** — Can a local-only user and relay user on same team see each other?
4. **Team isolation** — NATS subject hierarchy for multi-tenant relay?
5. **Freemium model** — Default hosted relay should offer a free tier with volume limits, with option to bring your own Synadia/NATS account for higher usage.
6. **/send and /cr** — Design pending. Data source and persistence model TBD.

## Client Architecture

New module: biff.relay with:
- RelayClient — wraps nats-py, handles connect/disconnect/send/subscribe
- RelayMessageStore — POP model: pull unread, ack-and-delete
- RelaySessionStore — presence via NATS KV store

Dual-mode: local (filesystem) or relay, selected by relay_url in .biff file.

## Exit Criteria

A distributed team can communicate end-to-end through biff across machines using the default hosted relay or their own self-hosted instance.

title: Data models: Message, UserSession, BiffConfig
close_reason: Frozen pydantic models: Message, UserSession, BiffConfig, UnreadSummary. 25 tests, all quality gates green.

title: Status bar notification: write unread state for Claude Code status line
description:
Dynamic tool descriptions are model-visible only — the human user has no visual notification in Claude Code UI. The spike confirmed this UX gap.

Claude Code's status bar is a configurable shell command (runs locally, can read files). Pattern: biff writes unread state to a well-known file (~/.biff/data/unread.json), and a status bar script reads it to display a live unread count.

Deliverables:
1. Biff writes unread summary to a local file whenever unread count changes
2. Provide a sample status bar script users can configure in Claude Code settings
3. Document setup in README

Depends on the message watcher (biff-9xj) which detects unread count changes.

CLI entry point with transport flag
close_reason: CLI entry point shipped in PR #5 (biff-x73): typer app with serve command, --transport stdio|http, --user, --data-dir, --host, --port

Verify: (1) cross-user visibility works through Claude's tool calls (plan, who, finger), (2) presence lifecycle end-to-end (biff on/off visible across sessions). Spike on SDK capabilities first.
